Shippuden is an average anime. It's ruined by filler that isn't even interesting or good in the first place, constant reused flashbacks that taint the whole entire series, and the animation at times can be atrocious. (See Pain V Naruto, or ALL THE STILL SHOTS EVER SEEN) The fights can be fun, emotional, or awesome. The main story is nice, but falters at times. The sound can be the most annoying thing of the show at times, but can also be charming or pleasant. This show has over 400 episodes. If you are a person who likes 13 episode anime, then this series is going to be tough on you. If you don't like shonen, then stay away. If you're expecting romance, there ain't a lot of it, I gotta tell ya. There's only around four major moments out of over 400 episodes. If you want awesome action stuff, then this show may fit to your tastes.

My Thoughts on the Ending of Naruto
First thing first. I will miss Naruto like no other. I first came into contact with Naruto way back in the 7th grade of middle school when it used to air in English on Toonami. It was love at first sight. The date was September 10th, 2005. I eagerly awaited each week for new episodes, and Naruto never disappointed, even on its worst episode. Fast forward 9 years later, and I'm still eagerly awaiting each new episode every week, even though I have already finished the events of the manga. Critics of Naruto say that the anime/ manga hasgone on for way too long and that it should have ended earlier; it's no longer good. I can't deny that Naruto has a ton of plot holes, but even so, the author has given me something to consistently look forward to for 9 years. How many anime series can you say have done something like that for you? 


Moreover, my interest in Naruto is not solely tied to the plot. To this day, I've bought 12 Naruto games and counting. I love the Naruto universe. I love the characters. I love the powers. I love the action. I love the voice actors. All of the Naruto games I own do an amazing job at recreating the characters from the series and letting you feel as though you are the character. When I choose Sasuke in the Ultimate Ninja Storm series, I feel like I become Sasuke. All of his powers from the show, I can command at the tips of my fingers. I'm the one using the Fire Style: Fireball Jutsu, and I'm the one unleashing Susanoo. As a result, the joy I get from being my favorite characters in these games heightens the amount of pleasure I take away from the series itself. 


It's been a couple weeks since Naruto ended, and it's still hard to believe it's over. When I read the final chapter, I honestly didn't want to turn the pages. Seeing all of the characters that started off at 12 years old become adults, get married, and have kids, really got believing that it is in fact over--the end of a generation. I was 12 years old myself when I began watching Naruto, now I'm 21. In a way, I feel as though I've grown up with these characters and that my youth is also approaching it's end soon. In the coming years, I'm not sure if I will ever experience an anime that has done what Naruto has done for me ever again. I'm really sad that my journey with Naruto is rapidly approaching it's end, but I'm also thankful for these past 9 years. Arigatou gozaimasu, Masashi Kishimoto.

As viewers we are able to see Naruto's growth as a character from an immature brat to someone who can truly understand the pains of mankind. The only downside for me about this anime is how long you must wait forthe episodes to come out. I've been watching Naruto since I was in 6th grade and its been 10 years.

NARUTO SHIPPUDEN, for now, is one of my favorite animes of all time. Despite this receiving the highest rating of ten out of ten, I do believe this show still has flaws (a bit of them). Also spoilers.
Let me just get out of the way what I don’t like about the show. Firstly, as you can probably guess- the convoluted nature of the war arc. The worst part of it comes down to Obito post unveiling with all the ten tails garbage. And then, to top it off- the twist of Black Zetsu being the manipulator and bringing back Kaguya. See, I was entirely finewith Madara, who made morse sense to be the final antagonist. His relationship with Hashirama was really well developed in flashbacks and had great purpose. I really enjoyed Obito when he was under the persona of the masked man (Madara). He had this menacing voice and sense of intrigue. But then he loses that voice since it’s actually Madara’s and has this terrible raspy voice. While I’m actually fine with Naruto being the good side of the coin while Nagato was the bad side juxtaposition, it just didn’t work well with Obito and Naruto. I do not feel bad for Obito at all. I just never connected to him, and the fact that Naruto said he was the “coolest guy” was just baffling. Obito’s motivations were good on paper. Witnessing Kakashi’s accidental murder of Rin and life spiraling out of control and just looking to seek her out again. I just never fully connected with it and it slightly held down the arc. Kaguya is self explanatory, just because she is the most powerful, she isn’t a good antagonist. Her flashbacks were boring and she had no depth. Naruto and Sasuke being the descendants of Ashura and Indra was also pretty dumb and felt a bit forced. That’s about it regarding my flaws about the war, I thoroughly enjoyed most of it. 


My second problem with the show is the filler and the way the show is structured. I’m not necessarily angry about filler episodes itself since you can just check which ones are which online and just skip them. I’m more annoyed at the way recaps are done at the beginning and how episodes are specifically structured. I feel really sorry for everyone watching it while it was still airing. Despite it being a staple of shonen and the reason being is because of its production being weekly, it ends up not holding up well post fact when you’re going through the series all at once. The fan edit Naruto Kai apparently addresses these issues, but it’d be interesting if an official cut was made by the creators themselves. 


That’s about it. There’s some small things that bother me a bit but I love pretty much everything else about the show. 


This is complimenting a bit of the original Naruto more but Shippuden continues the trend of great world building. The Shinobi world is so expansive with just so much history behind it. We get a better view at all the different villages which all have different aesthetics. The Sand Village’s establishment at the beginning with them explaining how they can’t grow medicine so easily added to the story in an interesting way. Also learning about the beginning of the Leaf Village with Hashirama and Madara just added so much depth and finally learning the story behind the statues at the Final Valley was great. 


The art design within the show is amazing as well. Every character has got redesigned for the season and I believe for the better. Naruto has a much more sleek design with the black instead of blue. And while the Akatsuki robes were featured in the original- they’re just so dope. Also the quality of the show just increased ten fold due to more technology being available and a higher budget. 


The music in the original Naruto was great, but Shippuden’s managed to top it. The show opts for more violin and orchestra to present a darker aura for this new era of Naruto. Every track plays at a perfect time, always making each scene as effective. The Hurricane Suite is one of my favorites. While having dark pieces, it also shines with more triumphant music. These songs add so much to the atmosphere in every way. Also the Shippuden OP1 and ending 1 are a banger. The first thirty episodes got me so hyped every time I’d watch and finish one. Also, OP2’s YOU ARE MY FRIEEEEEND is pretty catchy I can’t lie. The rest of the OPs are alright, not that great. 


The thing I primarily love about the show is my emotional connection to the characters. I genuinely care about most of these characters and their backstories tend to be really sad. I’ve shed some tears during this show with its handling of grief. The scene after Asuma’s death where Shikamaru and his father are playing shogi and he flips it over and whales out in tears. That is just a powerful execution that just sends chills to my core. I care deeply for all these characters, despite this show sort of shoving a few of them off to the side- most of them have had their development. Besides shoving Rock Lee and Neji to the side, Kishimoto knew which of the characters weren’t really that interesting and focused on a lot of better ones. Specifically Shikamaru who has developed so brilliantly from the small little slacker into absolute genius leader. Meanwhile, we have the central conflict of the whole show - Naruto and Sasuke. You care so much for Naruto and feel for him that he just wants his friend back but for a while, you just can’t understand why he keeps bothering. And as the series continues to progress, you finally see how deep that friendship meant to Naruto himself and how Sasuke’s repressed feelings for still thinking of Naruto as a friend is slowly revealed. The show is full of emotionally touching stuff but to name a few, Itachi’s reanimation death, Naruto after Jiraiya’s death, Minato with Naruto, etc. 


Adding to the emotional core, is the superb voice work done in Japanese. Every actor has a unique voice that perfectly fits their character. Naruto’s voice is giddy and high pitched yet not annoying. He’s kind and genuine. Every actor pours their heart out into the role, with bursts of anger and fits of sadness. You feel these moments so much more with this excellent showcase of acting. 


Another great part of the show is the thematic value and moral grey area presented. While the first Naruto showed up the glorious, fun parts of Konoha, this one flips everything on its head. It questions every “morally right” piece in the series and the idea of shinobi. Itachi Uchiha’s revelation is also a perfect example of this moral grey area. A lot of people will quickly hate him due to his decision seeming too grandiose and horrifying to slaughter his clan for the sake of the village. Others will realize how this decision does not have a good answer. It’s the worser of two evils. If Itachi didn’t kill the Uchiha, and joined them in a civil war. Danzo would most likely have gathered all neighboring villages to attack against them. The series, while somewhat still celebrating him, has the perfect send off for him when he tells Sasuke that he never has to forgive him but he’ll always love him. Nagato’s entire purpose as Pain, leader of the Akatsuki, presents another moral grey area between him and Naruto. The cycle of hatred continuing. Humans just don’t have the capability to create peace since we always lust after violence. You can relate to Nagato’s ideals and after learning everything - you know his actual true quest was for peace. Sasuke’s arc of wanting to change the village and seeks to be the Hokage also flips the ideology of the Leaf being a perfect system in contrast to Naruto’s constant hope to become this Hokage figure. 


The animation primarily was well done with a few small mishaps every now and then. The most annoying part of the show is during some fight scenes, the outlines on characters disappeared and they looked a bit strange when fighting. Despite this, the fights always had a sense of excitement and energy. 


A common complaint is the show delves into a Dragon Ball type series once everyone’s power continues to rise and rise but I disagree a bit. I feel as if the show has always held onto that idea of strategic tactics but it ended up becoming on a much larger scale. Despite all the tailed beast forms and Susano’os, there was always scheming going on against Obito, Madara and even Kayuga by the end of it. One of my favorite arcs is the Hidan/Kakuzu storyline where the amount of strategy is absolutely brilliant. Usually when strategies are at full form, it’s due to the genius of Shikamaru in the series. 


The pacing of the show is also surprisingly a plus. While always remaining interesting, the show uses a slower pace to build up tension and character. Naruto’s rise to god-like power was absolutely justified by how much we’ve seen him struggle and be below a lot of his comrades, and the sweat and tears behind his training. It was perfectly built up as he continued to train to be able to control Kurama. The only arc that overstays its welcome by a long shot is the full war arc and spanned out way too long. 


There is so much more to say, but this was my attempt to explain my love for the show. One last note, fuck the english dub for this show.

Above all, anime is a journey. Each different show carries its own distinct narrative fueled by a cast of characters residing in a setting; one thing that separates anime from the majority of mainstream Western television is this fact, that this industry of Japan puts in the effort and grunt work to adapt manga and novels and light novels and video games and create its own original work that follows a continuous story that’s not episodic. Now there are plenty of episodic anime like Cowboy Bebop and Mushishi; but for the most part, this medium is known for running multi-episode stories on television. Shows likeOne Piece, Dragon Ball, and Naruto that air for 10+ years are rare west of Japan, and for obvious reasons. Such commitment requires significant amounts of money, time, and human capital.


The longer a journey goes, the more you grow to love the characters, obviously. One immensely popular show that’s by all rights really good, Game of Thrones, in Western television has aired for seven seasons so far since 2011. And that’s enough time, plus the time progression within the story, to cherish certain characters as they’ve grown throughout. I’ll name Arya Stark as a prime example.


I mentioned Naruto earlier. This amazing anime aired from 2002 to 2017 for a total of 126 (Naruto) + 262 (Naruto: Shippuuden) = 388 episodes or approximately 142 hours, or 6 days, and that’s not counting filler. That’s also not counting Boruto: Naruto Next Generations, which may also be quite long. Compare this to Game of Thrones, which takes up 2 days. If we’ve been able to grow to adore certain characters in Game of Thrones after 2 days, then all the more so for Naruto, wouldn’t you think?


But I digress. My point is, that regardless of the various flaws in Naruto and Naruto: Shippuuden, it’s worth watching to go through this journey and see Naruto’s way of Ninja. You must consider Naruto and Naruto: Shippuuden together as one cohesive whole; although the latter is significantly more mature and improved on many points. Flashbacks are crucial to the characters’ development in Naruto; in the same way, when you look back to little annoying Naruto in the first episodes, and compare him back then to who he is now as (spoiler alert, but we all knew it was coming) Hokage, like seven hells, the growth is stunning. One of Naruto’s strong aspects, if not its strongest aspect, is its characters. Not only are they well fleshed out for the most part, but the way they interact and display their emotions, especially when amassed over 15 years, make them realistic in a way that One Piece and Bleach aren’t able to convey. It’s difficult to describe each of them with one word; right now I was going to write something like “Shikamaru’s nonchalance, Sakura’s kindness”, but then realized the futility. It would do these shinobi injustice to describe them thus; as two-dimensional they are on the screen, they’re completely three-dimensional to my heart. The main characters in particular -- Naruto Uzumaki, Sasuke Uchiha, Sakura Haruno -- these three are just… human.


I could end this review right here. I could say that the journey itself with these ninja is worth alone. But I won’t, because the Naruto universe presented through the anime has so much more to give you. From now on, I’ll be focusing on Naruto: Shippuuden, which let me tell you again, is much better than Naruto. So when you watch Naruto and aren’t too intrigued by the no. 1 most unpredictable ninja, keep in mind that this is just a prequel, an extended prologue, to the true story that lies in Naruto: Shippuuden.


I’ll start with the soundtrack. Yeah, it was kind of annoying, those tribal-esque war cries in Naruto, that played whenever Naruto would bust out a new technique. But Shippuuden brings you an intense score of Star Wars Duel of the Fates-esque dark choral majesty to back certain antagonists that are SO BADASS. They’re so cool that I actually didn’t want them to lose. The way they talked with each other, showing their cold personalities supported by crazy strength, oh my I really liked those guys and once the story moved on the show actually lost some of its dark hue that had made it so appealing.


And this is what really distinguishes Shippuuden from its counterparts like One Piece, Bleach, Fairy Tail, etc. The main villains are easy to empathize with. They have legitimate reasons for doing what they do. They’re not even evil to the sense of the word, they’re just trying to enforce peace in a war-torn world in their own revolutionary way. Again, this is a story in which I actually sided with the bad guys more than the good guys.


But that’s just one side of the coin gilded by the Muses. Shippuuden is high-octane wicked cool at times, but also deeply emotional at others. The soundtrack is also wonderfully beautiful and heartrending, for there are plenty of emotive moments. You can view the entirety of Shippuuden as a plot of salvation. Naruto, who possesses a power similar to Monkey D. Luffy that enables him to befriend enemies and change the hearts of those he meets, commits himself to saving a certain other character at the onset of Shippuuden. His almost blind devotion to this task, coupled with his lesser intelligence and sheer stubbornness, aren’t exactly desired traits but his willingness to believe and keep on striving, no matter the circumstances, make them meritable.


I’ll now discuss plot armor. This narrative-prevalent device is so endemic to shounen that it’s practically getting on my nerves. (Bleach, I’m talking to you.) Yeah we don’t want the good guys to die, but in real life it doesn’t make sense for like all the good guys to survive and all the bad guys to die. If you want to make the gravity of the conflict greater, then even some good guys should die. It’s not like the good guys were stronger than the bad guys at the start. Heck, more often than not the bad guys are much stronger.


Hunter x Hunter (2011) is a good example of a shounen in which good guys do die, and the main characters don’t always win their battles. Shingeki no Kyojin, although protecting the main characters extremely well, does kill off many supporting characters. One Piece, on the other hand, doesn’t even kill off the bad guys except all of those marine grunts that fell off the ships. The bosses are just soundly knocked out cold and wounded, but that’s it, they’re still alive.


Shippuuden does protect many of its good guys, but several pretty important ones do get killed, and each time the death carries a weight that resonates long afterwards. What’s more, being a world of shinobi who usually fight to the death, the loser does die (usually). There is that part of a certain jutsu that severely redefines plot armor, or should I say, plot reanimation, but that’s essential to a certain extensive arc so I guess it’s okay but I’m still not too sure about it.


Now let’s discuss the art. The improvement from Naruto, which was kind of hazy and reminiscent of classics like Evangelion, to Shippuuden, which has pleased me with its palette of gentle and warm colors, is legitimately aesthetic. I’ll even dare to say, that at certain moments, it rivals the plethora of modern 1- and 2-cour anime that are well drawn and styled. Towards the end I discerned another shift upwards in the quality, although by that time the characters’ faces became even more sharply defined, like what you see in anime produced by ufotable. I’ll also mention that for certain fights Studio Pierrot lowered the quality, but that’s OK, the fights are so fluid and berserk that it doesn’t really make a difference, and it actually makes it look more artistic.


Speaking of fights… damn. The fights in Shippuuden are some of the best I’ve seen in anime. That last fight in particular. Much of it is hand-to-hand, and watching shinobi battle it out, kicking, punching, putting hands together for some jutsu, summoning creatures, manipulating the elements, manipulating the laws of physics, it’s insane. They’re not quite as realistic as those in Gintama, nor as visually alluring as those in multiple ufotable works, but they’re certainly a sight to witness.


And lastly, I”ll mention the plot. Many have criticized the flow of antagonists up the climax of Shippuuden, especially how they were connected. The way I see it, the fact that Antagonist A was related to Antagonist B who was related to Antagonist C isn’t necessarily cause for complaint, but rather, cause for acknowledgement. Well, at least I personally like it when something the viewer suspects to be fact is in truth something deeper. The last conflict is somewhat stretched, though, looking back on it, but as we’ve seen since the beginning, a fight between shinobi isn’t as simple as stronger beats weaker; strategic use of jutsu and deception is as natural to shinobi combat as making webs is for spiders. That’s just how they do it, so as a matter of course any battle between strong characters is bound to last for some time.


Just kidding, I forgot to mention the filler. I really don’t like how this is the #1 cause of complaint for many people. Yes, it is the studio’s fault for creating so many filler episodes that plague the viewer’s experience each week. But you have to understand, people. The medium of anime is not like the medium of novels. Books are completed before publication, their stories finished. Anime are by no means finished, as each week a new episode that only furthers the plot incrementally is aired; furthermore, each episode is the culmination of many hours and days of grueling, collaborative work among many people, each contributing a different part from the music to the storyboards to the animation to the production aspects and so on. Watch Shirobako for more detail. What’s more, the anime industry is heavily pulled back by meager budgets. Before being adapted into anime, manga have to meet certain standards of popularity before studios feel like it’s worth spending the time and money hoping to make a profit out of a 1- or 2-cour or multi-season anime. Animators especially aren’t paid very much for the immense amount of work they put in. And the fact that anime that are based on manga, which are also being serialized on a regular basis, only leads to filler as well. If the anime in terms of storyline has met where the manga is, there’s obviously not enough material to adapt, and since the anime doesn’t want to bereave its fans, it resorts to unrelated filler to kill time. Also filler and/or recap episodes serve as backup for when the studio falls behind its deadlines, as they’re much easier to make.


So let me make this clear. Having filler, even lots of filler, doesn’t detract from the quality of the show itself. That’s a mere technicality. Obviously if the industry were better funded and its employees paid more, we would see less of filler. If Shippuuden didn’t have any filler, I can guarantee that its general conception would be significantly higher. Moreover, in today’s age of services like blessed Crunchyroll, you can skip the damned filler as easily as Itachi throwing kunai at targets.


Who cares about the length. Yeah you’re busy (I’m in college) and Naruto is crazy long and it looks like it may never end with this new show called Boruto. That’s original, isn’t it. The more episodes, the merrier. The more to enjoy this fulfilling journey with Naruto Uzumaki, the shounen who dreams of becoming Hokage and showing the world his unique way of Ninja.

Naruto as a series, is an incredibly complicated masterpiece. Assuming the person reading this has first finished the original Naruto series of our blond haired hero in his trademark Orange tracksuit, I will give a quick summary of some of the critiques I have of this series and what to look forward to in this next amazing sequel.
First of all, the soundtrack remains iconic and amazing. The openings remain  catchy and the soundtrack is both epic and marvelous. It tends to move away from the very fast-paced Japanese sounding instrumentals of the first series and enters into hymn and choir territory, especially with relevanceto characters of God-like status relating to the plotline.


Naruto shippuden is a very lore based series, and relates more towards philosophy and morality then the first series ever did. The battles are long, the speeches are longer. I assume Creator Kishimoto wanted his viewers to age up with the anime, beginning to question things they never did as a child. Therefore, expect the anime to become very complex and confusing at some points.


Unfortunately, The loveable Konoha  side characters that we independently learned and watched fight in the Chuunin exams and Sasuke retrieval Arc have a lesser role in the sequel. New characters and plot lines are introduced and many shinobis are cast to the side lines. The sequel is very much about focusing Sasuke and Naruto's bond and Naruto's own personal character development..

 I would argue that  the young shinobis still have much relevance, but less screen time in the main storyline as it progresses.

The meme of 'NAAAAAAAAAAAAAAARUTOOOOOOO' and 'SASUUUUUUUUUUKEH' is pretty much relevant to the series as Naruto fights further to bring Sasuke back to the village. ^_^


The new characters, especially the Akatsuki characters throughout the story, are super interesting and unique, so look out for them. They are all powerful individual shinobi with incredibly unique designs and jutsus. I found them to be the most enjoyable of the series and I hope the reader does too!


Naruto Shippuden may not have the carefree, often comedic,  nostalgic attitude of the first series main storyline, but it still provides a much enjoyable series and definitely a fantastic must see sequel to the first series to finally get a sense of closure.


I have repeatedly stated the 'main storyline' through out this review, because if you thought the fillers of the first series was bad after the Sasuke retrieval arc...then I have news for you. There is a lot of filler. If you only care about the story and not the alternative universes or random plot lines, you may want to stick to the main story line and skip the filler episodes, however some of the fillers I'd suggest keeping a look out for - especially the alternative universe ones, as they give an interesting opposite perspective to the main canon universe. Just try not to get jealous if the alternative universe seems more...idealic then the real world, blood thirsty shinobi world..that was my trap of watching them! I wanted things to be different! ^_^''


I hope you enjoy Naruto as much as the rest of us do, and watch our snarky, smart-mouthed Kyuubi protagonist manifest and develop into an amazing, strong-willed character with all his comrades behind him as he fights for what he believes to be right and true. Dattebayo!

An anime I was very fond, which I could label myself a true FAN (which is rare to me) but that unfortunately felt forced to drop.
The reason: Way too many many many fillers, plus the way that Sasuke guys suck lemons with his attitude and how Naruto won't just give up the prick just turned an anime I really liked into something un-watchable in only 95 episodes.
Plus, the story drags itself, the plot develops soooooo slowly that it makes me think Kishimoto should have been kidding his fans, to the point I felt it to be disrespectful to make an anime so mediocre like Shipuuden.

So, this review contains spiders and spoilers so watch out. This isn’t going to be a spoiler free review, because I feel like I need to talk about specific things in the show to fully explain my opinion and score of it. So if you haven’t seen the show and don’t wanna be spoiled, stop reading. 
Gosh… where do I start when talking about Naruto Shippuden? If I was to graph the quality of the series as it went on it would look a lot like a sin curve, with a big old dip right at the end of it. The individual arcs are justso inconsistent with one another in terms of quality. And for every great arc like the Pain Assult or Tale of Jiraiya the Gallant there is an equally bad thing, such as the seemingly endless, fillerific and boring Fourth Shinobi War arc. 


I guess if you were to list everything that happens in Naruto Shippuden as either good or bad then the good would potentially outweigh the bad by a tiny bit. But the problem is the bad bits are so bad that they really do drag down the great bits of the show. The show has this incredibly strong fetish for redeeming villains as they die, which I think is fine to occasionally do when it fits, but if you try to do it for every villain, which Naruto has a lot of, then it just feels so damn shoehorned. For example, Pain was an amazing villain and the two arcs with him as the major bad guy are some of the greatest anime episodes I have ever watched. It was tense, there was death, character arcs and consequences and Naruto’s fight with him truly was his graduation into being a fully-fledged hero after so long. Then when he was defeated Pain just decided to become good for poorly explained reasons and brought back everyone he had killed besides one person back to life. Effectively ruining and retconning most of the good stuff he as a villain did. And for what? To make you feel bad for the guy that just spent the last 20 episodes being ninja Stalin? Scenes like that just reverse half an arc really paint a picture that this story really wasn’t planned out very well, if at all. 


And that ending… it honestly goes against fundamental storytelling basics. To briefly explain it, after flip flopping between major villains like it was going out of style, it looked like Madara Uchiha would be it, the big baddie was finally settled. They managed to set it up so that he was the mastermind and cause of almost everything evil in the plot, from the nine-tails attack to the actions of most of the other major villains to the death of the girl that turned Obito into an evil person. They made him complex, making him not specifically evil, he just wanted everyone to not have to suffer like he did and have a blissful, perfect life. His plan had even succeeded, and only Naruto, Sasuke, Kakashi and Sakura were awake to stop him. And he had basically become a ninja god and is ready to unleash his full power on them. Then… he just is killed and replaced by someone we had heard about once beforehand. No foreshadowing about it, the villain the show had spent so long building up had been swapped with some random woman that was purely evil with vague motivations who is pretty quickly dispatched of. What was the point of that? To extend this crap even further? 


As for the fillers, well to be fair to they are better than the filler bits from the original Naruto, which were painful. Yeah it isn’t amazing television but filler arcs like the Three Tails one could be decent enough time wastes, and seeing the fillers flesh out some of the backstory of the world was nice. But the repeated flashbacks are a huge issue, I swear some of them were repeated like once an episode at some points. If I hear Obito say his stupid line about ninjas who abandon others being scum once more I think I might try to eat my desk. 


There is also a big problem with the side characters in that most of them are at points interesting but by the end of the show they are cast aside so that the show can focus just on Sakura, Kakashi, Naruto and Sasuke. And apart from Kakashi all of the main good guy characters are all just kinda… boring and bland. Except for Sasuke, he is just terrible and dumb. I get that in a series with as many side characters as Naruto you can’t focus on all of them but seeing characters like Sai get so much work done early on in the series to make him somewhat interesting just to be completely ignored by the end is unsatisfying. But that sums up the problem with Naruto, it takes one step backwards for every single one it takes forward. It has so much promise and goodness, then it has a bunch of lacklustre stuff and badness to follow it up. 


If I am being honest, Naruto Shippuden is enjoyable. There is enough good stuff and enough great stuff to entertain you, especially the bits directly from the manga. But if you are like me you will get frustrated watching it. It has the big problem where if a little more planning, polish and forethought was put into it then you would seriously have one amazing series. But the imperfections build, and they only get more and more noticeable as the show goes on. Heck I have barely spoken about the plot. But that is because the plot is hard to explain. Whilst not confusing it just goes all over the place, which isn’t at all helped by the constant passing of the ‘main bad guy’ torch. 


And I hope I am not sounding too harsh with this review, because I don’t hate this show. I want to like it, because I remember sections of it like the Team 10 vs Hidan and Kakuzu fight or the Jiraiya vs Pain battle and really want to like it. But then I remember the niggling problems that bubble and build up as the show goes on, so I can’t give it a higher rating than a 5. I mean the soundtrack is at least pretty damn great. Give it a go but don’t be surprised if you end up hating it for its flaws.

Naruto, one of those legends in japanimation. No need to introduce it at this point... So for starters, I'll just say that this review will focus more on the anime aspect than on the story, which comes from the manga.
I personnally really liked the manga, at least until the Pain arc.
STORY
Long story short, it depends on the arc. This should be something obvious today : when making literally HUNDREDS of episodes, you can't hit a perfect score. There are some very good arcs and some much less interesting.
Main strong point : from all those long-shônen anime/manga, Naruto is the most consistent, telling a straight story(from A to Z, without much detour).


Main weakness : the fillers. There are WAY TOO MUCH and some of them have to be watched as they contain bits of the canon story.



ART

This is what matters when making an anime adaptation of a manga. And I'll be blunt : the visuals were way too screwed up for me to enjoy Naruto.

- First, the drawings : they are way too simple. There are too few traits, and the colors are way too "unicolor".

- Then, the animation : this really depends on the episode. Some fights are simply amazing, but some of them are screwed up.

- Finally, there are no light effects (which is why it is all "unicolor").


Basically, the visuals are way too simple and irregular.



SOUND

Takanashi is a genius of music. The OST is great, although if I had to compare with Fairy Tail, I would prefer the latter because of the style. I'm not really fan of the "ninja music style" from Naruto...

As for the openings, there are so many...! Some of them are really good, some are not really memorable. I personnally really like the FLOW and Asian Kung-Fu Generation openings.

Overall it is really satisfying.



CHARACTER

Again, I won't really develop that point. Some of the characters are awesome, but I do feel like they could have done a better job with all those secondary characters. Naruto's friends aren't really interesting most of the time.



ENJOYMENT

Too many fillers, visuals too simple, and an overall resullt way too irregular. Because of those points, I really didn't enjoy the anime of Naruto. I do like some parts of the manga, and I was really expecting a lot from some arcs in the anime version, but wound up disappointed because the animation is sometimes awful.

Second, The Art  I give it 6 because of Studio Perriot they fucked up a lot of the episodes with bad art and animation but instead they gave us a few rather 100+ episodes or sowith good art and animation like episode 322 with Madara.

"In the ninja world, those who break the rules are scum, that's true, but those who abandon their friends are worse than scum." What a fun and long winded journey this was, but damn Im glad I experienced it. Last year I was one of few anime fans that never watched Naruto and now Im one of many to have completed the series. The prequel series ended with Naruto leaving his village to train with his sensei Jiraiya in order to prepare for his encounter with the Akatsuki. On the other hand Sasuke joined Orochimaru so he can get stronger in order to kill hisbrother Itachi. Due to the huge events waiting to come I had very high expectations heading into the sequel. The original was very good series with awesome fight scenes and did a great job on introducing the ninja world to the audience. I was both excited and nervous to see how the series as a whole would conclude hoping it would explore more of the ninja world and some of its characters. Now time to review the long sequel that is Naruto: Shippuden.***contains MINOR spoilers***



Story:8/10

A great long winded coming of age story with deep themes and s lot of depth. The series isn't just about ninja conflict but about people growing up. We see Naruto and his friends go from children to teenagers to grown up in a way that's very satisfying giving all the dark moments they go through. Where the story truly excels is its world building. We are given all of the ancient history of the ninja world and it's all greatly expanded upon in the series. We learn all about the villages and great nations on how they look and impact the story and how they all contribute with one another. Pacing issues at times are a problem as there are so many training sequences with Naruto to the point where it got kinda repetitive. The story was also dragged heavily with once again its use of flashbacks and filler. However having seen all the back and side stories really packed an emotional punch that added so much depth to the main plot and in some ways outshined it. The story had several great moments but towards the end made some bad choices during the Fourth Ninja War. Overall the storyline is better than most shonens that Ive seen thus far.


Art:9/10

Shippuden is a series that when it wants to it looks so damn GREAT. It became noticeable that during the more intense and violent battles of the series it uses different style animation that helps make the movements more fluid. This was done by animator Norio Matsumoto and notable examples of this would be Sasuke vs Deidara and Kakashi vs Obito. However the animation in the series wasn't always great and at times it looked too exaggerated. The most perfect example of this would be Naruto vs Pain where in some shots the fight looks so bad to the point fans made memes out of it. Usually in a long series keeping consistent animation is a hard thing to do and Shippuden does at times suffer from this but thumbs up for the series for not being afraid to use different animation for some of its scenes. Where the series really improve from the original were its editing and use of color palette. There are some views and angles of the series where it just looks downright beautiful that we didn't really get from the prequel. All in all it's the battles scenes where the art truly excels and its one of many reasons why Naruto is considered to have one of anime's most memorable fights. 


Sound:9/10

One of my favorite things about this series is how memorable most of the quotes are. "You presumptuously see yourself as the ruling powers, and distance yourself from death. Softened by peace, you've become thoughtless. Kill and be killed. Hatred connects the two." All of this was helped by great voice acting by the cast and there's so many quotes to choose from. The music overall is very good. Most of the tracks portraying some of the scenes more intense and emotional moments. Arguably the best track is Pain's theme song "Girei" it's a very dark and godly track that perfectly portrays the character. As for the opening and ending themes some were very good but some were okay. My favorite opening would have to be the first one "Hero's Come Back" from Nobodyknows. The OST's biggest strength were definitely the background tracks. 


Character:10/10

It is here where I think the series truly shines. The franchise as a whole is so character driven and really does an amazing job at making us feel for them especially the villains. There are some many characters that have their moments to leave an impression on the audience whether if it's from the use of backstory, interactions, personalities, or abilities. What makes this cast so fun is how much variety they have in their abilities. There are ninja who can spit fire, turn into paper, become giants, heal wounds, take over bodies, you name it and it really helps add joy to the cast as a whole. Character development is also big here as so many people learn and undergo changes from character arcs and make them complete. As with a lot of large casts giving depth to all is very tough and towards the end of the series a lot side characters do get pushed to the back to lead way for Naruto, Sasuke, and Sakura. It even throws in a villain at the very end with little to no build up and it really didn't help at all. Even so the series does such an amazing job at making most of its cast feel relevant to the storyline.


Final Verdict


Pros



+Strong coming of age story with great exploration of deep themes(war, discrimination, vengeance, etc)

+A dominate cast with a surprising amount of complexity and backstory

+Outstanding world building that completely fleshes out the ninja world

+The final battle between Naruto and Sasuke


Cons


-THOSE DAMN FLASHBACKS!!

-Narrative starts to lose momentum as the series progresses

-Fourth Ninja World War



Personal Favorites



Character(s): Kakashi, Pain, and Itachi


Arc: Pain Assault


Fight: Kakashi vs Obito



Boy what a long yet legendary series this was. Naruto is a series of highs and lows but its highs really do outshine the lows for the most part. The franchise is an iconic juggernaut with huge merchandise and sales and its hard to find people who haven't heard of it. It has strong storylines, great battles, awesome characters, deep moments, I would have to say that it's w/o a doubt one of the best shonens anime has had yet and it's a franchise that I see myself talking about for years to come.



Sub or Dub Recommendation: Sub

Salut à tous enfin une Review fait en français ! 
Je vais faire cette Review sur l'histoire complète même si on est sur Shippuden.
Premièrement, l'histoire ; Une histoire Incroyable remplis d'aventure, de rebondissement et de passage émouvant. I do have to say that most of the time I enjoy watching Naruto but it certainly has its flaws and is far from perfect. I also think that you can't just discard fillers as necessary and just discard them while writing a review. 
Lets start by looking at the most important part of an anime, the story.
The main story line is actually very well written and thought out. It gets me really into the anime and makes me want to keep watching all day if it were possible. Now the flaw are the fillers. Yes I know that fillers are necessary and I amnot saying that I disapprove of fillers. The problem I have with fillers in Naruto is the terrible quality and timing of them. If they were able to make a good storyline for them to follow during the fillers and not suddenly interrupt big moments in the anime I wouldn't mind that much at all.


There were even a few times where I dropped the anime in between because I got bored with it. But after a while I couldn't help myself to start watching again. The reason for this was the main storyline. Without the fillers I would have to give the story a 8 out of 10 but the fillers just take out too much.


The thing I have to like most of all are the characters. Al the important characters have their own background and there is no black and white way of looking at the. The bad guys are not all that bad, they all have there reasons and motivation why they are doing what they do. The only thing that bothers me is the recurring "Naruto" type character, that can perfectly relate with the lead character of the show. I feel like they are repeating the same character over and over with just a slight twist each time. 


So overall it is a good anime, and the main storyline is good enough to still make it enjoyable overall. I am still hoping that they'll remake the whole thing at some point and just remove all the filler material and also go over some of the artwork, because there were some moments wherein the animators seemed to be rushing.
A fantastic sequel to naruto with more in dept story with the characters and  action adventure surpasses the previous. The characters show more knowledge and maturity. Its a AWESOME ANIME TO WATCH.

Naruto shippuden or called filleruto, was great at the start, then fillers ruined it like crazzy!!! the arc now has been going on since 2013, and the latest 20 episodes have all been fillers, i dont understand whats going on? oh well, shippuden takes place 3 years after the first naruto anime, everyone you saw in the original anime has grown up, the characters in the start are really not that great, exept the main enemy group, later characters become better but are still one dimentional, like the animation, shippuden it feels like have gone threw so many diffrent animations, sometimes it looks good, sometimesawfull, right now its fair, one fight scene with naruto and a main enemy has the aboslute worst animation i have ever seen in an anime, i mean wtf. I have to say, this is one of the best anime I have ever seen. I've always neglected watching Naruto because of how big it is, but I finally took a chance, and finished it within 3 days because of how amazing the story development was. And now, Naruto Shippuuden is even better.
Story - 9
First of all, this an amazingly thought out story. From the history to the jutsu (ninja abilities), it all connected so well. The provided explanations for how the characters execute their abilities, it just can't compare to one piece, with how you eat some devil's fruit and gain powers. I understandthe stories are completely different, and one piece is one of my favorites, but Naruto is just so much better when it comes to being realistic, to the point that I wouldn't be surprised if there were actually ninja who could mold chakra in this world. Also, Naruto (shippuuden) is not one of those anime where the main characters are always able to win against an enemy. But that's what I love about it, and with how the main chars aren't just given massive powers from the start. They have to work for their skills. And even in the most dire situations, they aren't able to get past it.


Art - 10

Unlike "modern day" anime such as SAO, the character profiles aren't just smooshed at the mouth, nor are the nostrils just magically not there. All parts of anatomy are present! Other than that, the art is amazing, especially in battle scenes. Just watch it. You can understand what I mean.


Sound - 10

One of the main things that makes this anime so good is the ost and op... and the necessary, icky, but realistic, sound of weapons piercing flesh. The openings are really suitable to the anime, and it's a nice selection of music. Especially OP 3 (watch the anime to hear what it sounds like! don't just go to google). And then there's the sound tracks of the animation. Probably one of the best I've heard. Although each OST is suited to their situation and/or scene, it's mainly the sad tracks that wow me. They convey the perfect feeling of sorrow, whilst at the same time emulating the theme of Naruto. What I mean is, at sad moments, you feel sad, and it sounds like a typical Japanese instrument, which, in the Naruto time period, that's what people would be using. Tabun.


Character  - 10

Here we go! Well, actually, to see the char development you'd have to start from Naruto, when they were actually... developing. But from the start of Naruto to Shippuuden, the characters never fail to amaze me. If you had seen Naruto, you would assume the evil characters are just evil, the side characters are just boring, and the main characters are just the epitome of justice. No. All of the characters have another side to them, and I hadn't known that until watching Shippuuden. Even the side chars. Down to their family history, all of the characters are just so well developed. I hadn't even known (***spoiler*** well it's not that important anyway) Asuma was Sarutobi-sensei's son until season 2. Not to mention, who would have thought Naruto's teacher would be some perverted hermit, instead of a clean, know-it-all peacemaker. Like Konohamaru's teacher, you know, the guy with the glasses. JK.


Enjoyment - 9

I thoroughly enjoyed the anime the whole time, EXCEPT the fillers. Definitely not the fillers. eaughh. That doesn't mean all the fillers though. I just mean those fillers that don't show any character development, just another mission, or another waste of time. But that's only a small fragment of the anime. Shippuuden that is. For those of you who have seen Naruto, remember that massive section of fillers? Again, eaughh.


Overall - 10...00000000

:D

Now I know you might be surprised of my score since Naruto Shippuden seems it had gone through a lot of hate lately mostly because of the filler episodes however, it didn't seem to bother me that much. Sure, there are some fillers from a few episodes ago but it will be until episode 100 after they stop with the "overwhelming" amount of fillers in each episode.
---
Story:
The story is about the same Naruto we knew from the main series however, now that he is more mature he will get over following Sasuke all the time and focus on training to become a hokage (P.S. Iwas just joking, the whole plot now focuses on this whole part).


Leaving the jokes aside, although the story focuses on Sasuke throughout the whole series, like OnePiece, it shows how hard it is to achieve something you want after you see how much you have to go in order to accomplishing it. 


Art: As you *may know*, long running series start off with lower graphics and then grow in quality by a lot although the graphics it started off didn't bother me at all, It's just the way they try to covering things to save more budget is really bad. No further comments there. (8/10)


Sound: Surprisingly enough, I just love the Naruto Shippuden soundtracks since I am a big fan of Japanese instrumental songs, However! It could get really annoying as it gets overused as many other long running series do the same thing to safe money which is understandable, but I didn't feel like they were as good as in the main series, remember those sad soundtracks which really gave you the vibes when they started? Well, none of these here which was really my main disappointment. (7/10)


Character: If there's something Naruto Shippuden has improved in from the main series, it would be the animation and characters. The characters have evolved a lot in mental as well as physical strength (ex: Shikamaru) which also made the Naruto series somewhat more *mature*. 


Enjoyment: Too lazy to continue so ==> (8/10)


Overall:

In conclusion the story is pretty good executed although there are bits missing here and there.

Hope you enjoyed my boring review.

This series is a spectacle in the shounen genre. Let us not mince words!! This show succeeds in utilizing its cast of secondary characters due to a long episode count and filler episode budget that the animation studio has. Battle sequences are epic where new abilities need to be learned for our main character to keep up with the looming threats wanting to destroy the shinobi world. The villains in Naruto are very fleshed out. Naruto Shippuuden gets you invested in the main characters and rooting for them quickly into the first Akatsuki onslaught. The filler episodes fall into the "hit-or-miss" category, so if youare watching for the story or over-the-top shounen fights, you might wanna have a list of filler episodes ready so that you can accelerate thru the long episode count. I don't suggest marathoning such a long-running shounen; save your sanity. But this shounen is worth the watch!!

Good : 
Interesting premise and world, magic system that allows for many enjoyable fights, interesting character designs, characters with relatable motives.
Bad :
-Characters
Naruto :
  a)He started as a likeable kid with troubled life that could be overbearing at times but tried his best. He became annoying when he would spout the same things over and over again while never actuall achieving anything , diving head first into the enemy without thinking and getting his ass kicked.
  b)In Shippuden he shed that immaturity and became more bearable.
Unforutnately he still had his dumb moments that completely messed the tone in many instances. His immaturity also clasheswith the tone and style of the rest of the series. Characters like Luffy are ok to be "dumb" because the whole world of the manga is kind of silly and ridiculous with over the top scenarios, locales and cahracters. Every character on his crew is a bit of a nut in their own way, and many characters in the rest of the series are too so it doesnt feel out of place. But it does in Naruto.

  c)Also he was still an almost useless fighter. Sasuke had managed half a dozen different Jutstus in the 2 year timeskip, Naruto not only learned nothing but he couldnt even do rasengan without a clone.

Apart from Pain he never had a decent fight with an equal oppoenent to show his skills and competence. After that he just uses the Fox which throws most ninja techniques out the window.



-Sakura :

Most annoying character and impossible to like.

Has an unhealthy obsession over Sasuke, even after all his crimes and attempts to kill her making her look like an unhinged ex-girlfirend with Battered Wife Synrome than an independent strong character.

The antics with Naruto where she gets angry and slaps him were never funny, just cringy and annoying making her look like a bitch.


-Sasuke

He started off interesting if a little emo.

He opened up, he made friends, but had to leave them for his own purposes. Ok so far.

Aftet the 2 year timeskip he goes full-on edgy emo and tries to kill them for no good reason. It made sense to abandon them in favor of training under Orochimaru, not kill them.

He puts on a permament poker face being unable to show any emotion at any time.

Plus after al the shit he did, he was forgiven way too easily.


-Hinata

Annoying too high pitched voice even after she became a teen, too timid even for a timid personality, too obsessed with Naruto, barely any good interaction between them.


-Karin

That was a big missed opportunity. After she as almost killed by Sasuke her dialogue made it sound like she realised the truth and would forget Sasuke coming to her senses. She observed Naruto and how he was so much "brighter" than Sasuke. Given how they were also form th same clan it was a ripe opportunity for interesting character development betweeen them.

Naruto could realise he was not alone, Karin the same. They could become close, bond over their troubled childhoods and support each other in the coming battles.

But her character was wasted and the very next scene with her, she just still craves Sasuke's dick for some reason.



-battles :

That was hit n' miss.

Some fights, especiallu the early ones were interesting with various strategies and techniques being used in creative ways to make dynamic battles.

While however some characters like Sasuke or Shikamaru were given interesting fights, the protagonist himself Naruto most of the time had lame ones. Others like Lee, had onnly brute force but ultilised it in the same way we see Chackie CHan and other artists use it in fulm so it was entertaining.

Naruto offered none of the 2 : neither brain fights nor strength fights

He usually just used brute force instead of his brain, even when the opponents were much stronger and it was obvious it wasnt working.

He never learned any elements to supplement his arsenal, he never improved upon them.

HE learned th wind elements which he used to create his super rasengan and then he totally forgot about it. he didnt create any new technique that was less dangerous than that.

He went from 0-100 with no in-between.

Towards the end, the ninja fitghts are almost gone and we just have gods playign with each other so...whatever.

It's way too old....back when I was in school watching some random Anime, I was told by my friend that a new Anime named Naruto is going to start soon in CN. That's when everything was changed....!!
I have seen the first episode, to me it was amazing. It captivated me completely. That Anime had made a great impact on my life. I've learned so many things from that Anime. High in morals, it changed my way of thinking.
I'm here to write a review on Naruto Shippuden which is a part of Naruto's world.
To all Naruto/Naruto Shippuden Haters who think that Naruto isn't the best anime.....Idisagree with you...coz is not only the best it's greatest of all time. And one more thing, Naruto/Naruto Shippuden is not for immatures and those who run out of patience very quickly.


I consider it as Masterpiece.


I do hate fillers...but I like them as well because even fillers in Naruto/Naruto Shippuden has something to do with the morals and the way of living.


We all know that story revolves around a knucklehead Ninja who wants everyone to acknowledge him. With help his friends he was able to finally achieve it.


There are so many reasons why I like this Anime....they are:


1. Great Story(High in Morals)

2. Deep Characterization(every character in this Anime teaches some good to us, you will get attached to them)

3. Evolution(yes evolution in everything - in the story, in characters, in fights, in techniques), I like new things...!

4. Emotions, Relationships 

5. Side Stories(yes side stories of other characters - they are really cool)

6. Memorable heroes and villains(yes though we have one main protagonist we have several side heroes and villains with their awesome stories)

7. Logic(logic in every Jutsu development, in every fight)

I've seen Anime with higher ratings but no logic in their battles, training.(IDK why people like something which doesn't support logic)

8. Explanation - everything is explained in detail.

9. Life Lessons - yeah I have learned so many things from this Anime characters.


Almost all characters are my favorite but the special ones are Itachi, Naruto, Nagato(Pain), Shisui, Orochimaru, Madara, All Hokages, I will never forget Akatsuki....they are amazing..!!


My most favorite episode is a filler....yes it's a filler, a filler in which writer expressed his views about the real world, real people, what it is to create and what it is to destroy, what is life, what is love, what is power? what we can do with our life and how we can be helpful to others!! So many things were just taught just in a single episode. The name of that episode is Ninja Creed.


There are so many things that I wanted to explain here but people will get bored of my review so I'm ending this here. 


Keep watching Naruto Shippuden coz anime is still going on and the rest of the episodes will amaze us just as the previous ones did.


Sayonara!!!

One of the most overrated anime in the century. I understand that the manga could appeal to a lot of people but frankly, the anime was really bad. I have counted in total 223 filler episodes on 500. Don't you think that almost half of the episodes of the anime is way too much? Moreover, 90% of these filler were not interesting at all. I know that they put it there so the anime doesn't catch up to the manga but it was way too unsatisfying. It is because of these filler that I dropped the anime for a long time. The art was notbad, I mean some jutsu were kind of original and pretty.

The OST/Openings were good too. If they had just put the manga stuff, I would probably rate it with 8/9 but the way they handled the anime was bad.


NB: The characters were not really interesting, some characters were really likeable like Jiraya, Minato, Naruto, Shikamaru,... but on all the characters(those that we know the name at least) I was able to like only 5-8%.


NB+: How come Shippuuden has a better grade than the first series. I think the first one is way better.

I grew up with naruto, I watched him grow, get stronger and eventually achieve his goal. I learn many life lessons from naruto and it will forever a part of me and the anime/manga that had made me the way I am now somehow...so, I am really bitter about saying how shippuden change my high opinion about it. 
With it's enormous amount of fillers, the story was hard to follow at some point and I lost my interest pretty fast. The fourth ninja war was dragged for too long in my sense, with always a new final boss showing up, the dead that are broughtback to life, and again fillers with new characters that sometimes appeared out of nowhere and weren't even in the manga. And this is my personal opinion, the end was really lame...I mean, the fight between naruto and sasuke, how they settled thing once and for all was great but I found the fact that they both survived stupid, and that was only to reach a sequel in Boruto which is...no comment....only a way to save the franchise and make it go on. Maybe not kill off naruto and sasuke but at least one of them (sasuke) but both you'd have been better and the spirit of naruto would have stayed in people's memory. Well, that would have been so much more better. Anyway even though shippuden was overall average to me, Naruto (from the old days) will forever stay my treasure.

Naruto Shippuden is the continuation of Naruto. Naruto Shippuden is definitely better than Naruto. Here's is what I thought about the show so far:
Story: The story is pretty interesting and unpredictable. You not going to know what going to happen next. Some episodes might be drag on and a big amount of flashbacks are shown in almost every episode so it might be a little bit boring for some people. If you are a patience person then you can make it through the show, the show gets better as time goes on.
Art: The art is a step-up from the original series but I woudn't saidthat the art is great. I noticed that Naruto Shippuden uses different animation in different arcs. The show never stick with one animation. Some episodes the animation might be really good and some episodes the animation is just horrible. Overall, most episodes have decent animation so the art wouldn't be a big problem.


Sound: Naruto Shippuden's Soundtrack is not as good as the first series. However, The OPs and EDs are great.


Character: Naruto Shippuden have a variety of characters with different personalities. Some characters had developed while some other characters didn't develop much (except their appearance). The characters in Shippuden are lovable so I beleived that you guys will find at least one person that you like.


Overall: Naruto Shippuden might be boring in some cases but if you are patience, you will be rewarded BECAUSE WHEN NARUTO SHIPPUDEN IS GOOD, IT'S GOOD.

I'm sorry.. it's just so bad in my opinion of course.
The art is dumbed down from the original series, the sound is... pretty much the same stuff. The character development for the new characters is pretty good...
Enjoyment.. is bad because.. well... FILLERS... EVERYWHERE... it tries making you bored out of your mind or on the edge of your seat so even the most pointless event seem exciting. It's dragged out so long. I believe it should only be around 50-100 episodes. I quit watching the original Naruto at like 80 then started watching Shippuuden because my friend really likes it, but we literally skimmed throughthe first 40 episodes within about 2 hours, and I did not miss any details at all. I discussed the main bad points about Naruto with my friend and he agreed with all of them which include the ones that I have talked about before.\n
They're overcomplicating it in my opinion, and should stay focused on the main problem, create "sub"-problems that lead up to ending the main conflict, which seem to be the problem with a lot of mainstream shounen anime. They try making a series as long as possible to make the most money out of it rather then creating a good story, with good art, and characters that a person will thoroughly enjoy.\n\n
Overall, Naruto Shippuuden gets a 5/10, There are a lot of shorter anime series that gets to the point of the anime which are much more exciting, because they cram all their interesting ideas into a short time span rather than having a single event drag out over a term of 3-10 episodes.

All I have to say is that Naruto Shippuuden is one of the best Animes you'll ever see. A lot of people disagree, either because they're hipsters who try to dislike anything that's popular, because of it being popular, or, because shonen is mostly for young boys and they're under the distorted conception that anything for kids is crap. Naruto Shippuden is a good Anime in my opinion. I know many people look upon Naruto as being "mainstream" and somehow inferior to other Anime, they are right and wrong.
I like Naruto because of the troubled lives that the Shinobi live and the morals that the show tries to impart to the viewers although that is lost on most people.
Shippuden has a more refined feel than Naruto part 1 and that's most likely due to the development and maturity of the characters. Naruto as always stimulates powerful moments of emotional empathy from the viewers and always transfers some wisdom to the viewer, most notably relatingto friendship, family and duty. 


The overall main story arc is interesting and has many interesting developments which show what it's like to live the ninja life. There is Naruto's humor which still creates funny moments although that isn't as big of a part of Shippuden as it was in Part 1. The combat is also interesting and fun to watch.


Now for the bad parts that makes people view Naruto in a negative way. There is many fillers which seem completely pointless and while that's not really an issue if you are able to trick yourself into liking them, It is very boring to watch. There are repetitive elements which can become stale after a while but if you become a fan you can overlook the repetitiveness. 


In short: Naruto Shippuden isn't close to being perfect, but you will learn to care about the characters, mostly Naruto which greatly helps enjoy the show. It's interesting to watch but requires a lot of time since there is so many episodes and if you watch part 1 also (I suggest you do) then that adds up to quite a lot of time. Perhaps find a list of filler episodes and skip them. 


Give it 10 episodes to see if you enjoy it.

I don't even know where to begin. When I started watching the original Naruto it was great, tons of potential but once it hit shippuuden it didn't just go down hill, it flew down vertically with no stop in sight. It's depressing to see an anime with a lot of potential be destroyed. As it continues it looks like they are trying to squeeze out all the money possible out of this story instead of just ending it. Many people would disagree with me and a majority wont really give arguments other than being a fan boy but anyway here's my review.
Story - Originally thestory was supposed to be about a failure ninja who is hated by everyone because of the beast in him. He cries all the time, is extremely annoying to all his peers yet he still blames his beast for being hated. Anyway, the whole plot to this anime is to create bonds, friendships, and get acceptance with the title of "Hokage". In the first part of the Naruto series that's exactly what he worked to do and now with shippuuden everything changes, no more bonds, no more friendship, it's just an anime that resembles some sort of animal trade using tailed beasts. Naruto continues to chase sasuke and even after all the advantages hes born with he continues to not be able to catch him. Theres virtually no training in this anime at all, just free powers given over and over. Villains are just a line of people controlling one another.


Art - Basic, Average, Modern, not unique. Most of the characters all look like they have been drawn using the same template. Just take off naruto's hair and eyes, throw in sasuke's hair and eyes, BOOM flawless.


Sound - The music isn't anything special, usually its an asain man yelling what sounds like "SEA SAW" at you with background music.


Characters - Not unique, very obvious copy of DBZ.

naruto - Easily resembles goku, orange suit, blonde hair, raised by an old guy(hokage), both become monsters with a tail. Only difference is while naruto cried his whole childhood, goku lived alone with innocence.

Sasuke - Very obvious copy of vegeta, from the hair, to the death of his whole race and getting revenge.

Jiraya - Narutos, frog sage, old, perverted teacher, very similar to roshi, goku's turtle sage, old perverted teacher. Even the way naruto received training was similar, both asked for a large breasted hot girl.


Enjoyment - At first it was enjoyable, now it makes you wanna rip your hair out at how ridiculous it is.


Overall - 5/10 - and with good reason.

Just like most of the people I know I also started watching anime from Naruto.. it is the best anime I ever seen.. best story.. best characters..  It's just perfect but the thing that bother me so much are the filler episodes..  I think no one is interested in fillers. They r ruining the whole anime by adding fillers.. for example in recent episodes (394 to onwards) what was the logic in showing chunin exams when both Naruto and Sasuke r dead?? Most people forget what Naruto is and what it is meant to be and start comparing it with anime that arrived a decade later. And it's almost impossible to assign numbers and evaluate a series like this one that has been running over a decade. Naruto was never a show made to compete with mind boggling story such as... I don't know let's say Cowboy Bebop for a lack of better example. But it was made in midst of a shounen revolution where the importance was placed on Friendship, goodness, and perseverance. 
Naruto is very little about ninjas. In fact it's very bad atportraying what ninjas are. But Naruto is creative at least. Taking this ninja genre and combining it into several martial and weapon arts to make this very unique show. Well unique is a bit subjective but whatever. I applaud the series for combining the natural elements, weapons, and even mixing human behaviors to create a world full of unique fighting techniques. 


Story wise, Naruto is about the character Naruto becoming the leader of his village. He is an orphan cursed with bearing a monster with him and the whole anime is about him overcoming the world of ninjas, which is filled with hatred and suspicion. See the series have some of the most fascinating characters. Each of them with their own background, although many of them could've been kept a secret for the better story progression and pacing. Many of these characters' actions are justified by their past and as the series progresses you can see how each of them changes and influences each other. However the best aspect of the series is also probably the worst aspect of it. While many main characters are given a good amount of attention and care and many of them are nurtured with logic, others just become fodder characters uttering 1 or 2 lines then their worth are never revisited again. 


The story of Naruto is about never giving up, making friends, and well, whatever standard shounens babble about. But Naruto is one of the few exceptions because Naruto is rarely a hypocrite and actually always stays around its core beliefs. As the series is ending, it's sad that many of the traits of the characters like Sasuke and Obito are reversing and villains are entering the infamous Dragon Ball complex (you enemy becomes bff lol), the main thing is Naruto remains Naruto: stupid and somehow still influential. 


After watching this series at different intervals and after watching other anime, I came to appreciate Naruto. Because I watched several long running shounen and nothing really even came close to the emotional appeal Naruto formed. I think I can safely say that this show truly keeps it promise and shows Naruto is a hardworking guy who becomes special. 


However, I still can't forgive this series for wasting the potential of so many characters, random power-ups, unnecessary glorification of Sasuke and Naruto (WE GET IT THEY'RE THE MAIN CHARACTERS) and Bleach-esque arse pulls. The fillers are downright horrible and let's not even explore the comedy. Seriously, many of the plot like Kaguya and other backstory could have been omitted, no they should have been omitted, to give Naruto a more refined ending but it is what it is. 


At the end of the day, Naruto is a good series about a guy never giving up as he faces challenge to save his friend and save his village. Indeed it is a tale of a gutsy ninja. Characters like Itachi, Jiraiya, and Pain are some of the noteworthy characters in all of anime. Naruto is a good series on what it stands for. Stop comparing it to high level, 13 episode series because all anime loses its lust after 500 episode mark. 


On a side note, this is not a proper review. Just whatever I feel about this series. I recommend it for the nostalgia and some really good fight scenes.
